last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56278512
Plus, if your AFV has a partly autonomous 100mm or so mortar and some ATGMs, and your squad is trailed by a bunch of small autonomous 60mm smart mortar launchers, sending serious firepower anywhere you point your optic becomes extremely quick. Same if your squad has a treaded drone or two with a heavier machine gun and/or grenade launcher (I'd think you'd probably want to make the targeting/weapons pod removable so infantry can carry it inside buildings and set it up in windows too). The service rifle is probably more only for very quick reaction situations and having to go door to door in rough terrain drones can't handle.

Given the plunging share of 18-25 year old men in rich nations, this sort of thing will become a top priority.

What does CQC look like in 20 years? With drones taking way more of a role in conventional ops, allowing for less use of manpower, you're probably looking at more specialized urban combat formations. Armor has come a long, long way since 1990 and ML and simulations are a huge materials science accelerator. More drones in urban combat = less weight carried for munitions = heavier armor possible, and you're already getting lighter and lighter level 4.

So IDK what that does for CQC. On the one hand, you want rate of fire, on the other you want to degrade plates rapidly and have a decent chance of disabling behind armor blunt force trauma injuries.

IDK if 6.8mm solves this problem long term though. If in 20 years something like "level 5" is around and common, you might switch to using 20mm flat trajectory grenades more and more often.

Or maybe we'll be surprised and there will be a huge jump in coil gun tech, in which case armor will again become fairly useless as 3mm penetrators hurled potentially multiple times as fast as current rifle rounds aren't getting stopped by man portable armor.

IMO we might see coil gun artillery by 2042, but probably not small arms being replaced until a good deal after that.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56278607
I highly doubt they DON'T become dominant.

First, wealthy nations have a soaring dependency ratio. Seniors will be 25+% of the population. They won't be able to afford heavy losses of young people.

Second, while I'm not a /pol/tard, there definetly seems to be an issue with recruiting migrants for military service. The willingness of first and second generation migrants to serve appears to be inverse to how well the group assimilates with their new country. Since migration will likely increase with the African population boom, this will also be a drag on recruitment.


There isn't any efficient, cheap way to deal with drones, especially as they get smaller, cheaper, and more numerous. How do you stop a bunch of rifle sized drones coming at your position from every angle at 10-3,000 feet above the deck? You can't be spewing flak above your head 24/7.

Active protection and having your own drones up will likely be the best way to counter them.

Of course, hard limits on silicone processing efficiency and battery life might temporarily cap drone efficiency. But only temporarily, wetware and hybots solve that problem. You can run a human brain, petaflops of processing power, off a Snickers bar. Evolution has already given us a model for computation orders of magnitude more efficient than our best processors. That's where the next big revolution will likely be. Hell, companies are already writing jpgs, mp4s, and ASCII text to DNA. A DNA hard drive lets you store the information content of the entire internet circa 2017 in a shot glass in a way far more stable than hard drives. The bio-information revolution is the future.

So 2150, maybe you don't even do urban combat. You just rocket in cannisters of hybots mutants the size of insects with a lethal sting and have them wipe the opposition. Bonus apocalypse points if you can make them reproduce on their own.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In Finland police has for decades been campaigning for people to report found explosives and unlicensed, unused and death estate weapons for collection. These are then picked up by police, or army pioneers in case of explosives.

Most unlicensed handguns are still WW2 bring backs, long arms typically hunting guns left unreported by death estates, etc.

Finnish gun law states that firearms and explosives voluntary reported to police will not result in legal actions (unless associated in crime).

Police also announces in medias of local and regional collection campaigns with special contact phone numbers for reporting guns. Recently in South-West Finland such campaign produced 449 contacts to Police and some 800 guns were picked up, mostly from elderly people older than 80 years of age, including 247 shotguns and 234 handguns of which most unlicensed and 98 explosives, of which 67 were military ones, a number which surprised the authorities.

In case of guns with likely sales value, guns surrendered can be sold with license holder picking up the gun from Police, or gun can be sent to National Police Authority´s auctions, held nowadays 3-4 times a year, where close to 500 guns are auctioned each time. Any proceeds of more than 50€ is paid to the gun's owner.

Auctions may include as new scoped hunting rifles and collectable guns. Guns are also bought for spare parts by gun smiths. However typically many old ordinary shotguns, rifles and pistols are simply not sold and sent to be melted.

Present more strict gun law regarding new handgun licenses (a minimum of 2 years of gun club proven practicing required) means that most handguns inherited will not be licensed to a next of kin and end up either in an auction or melting.

Examples of collected items:

https://poliisi.fi/-/lounais-suomen-poliisi-keraa-kampanjalla-aseita-ja-rajahteita

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56277149
No it isn't. Swords weren't a side arm, they were used as primary weapons all the time, alongside spears. It's more like saying "rifles or machine guns, which is better." You obviously want both. This is why militaries generally used both.

>>56273950
>History. Swords generally made up a minority of the weapons on the battlefield.

Massive generalization. Spears were more common overall, in part because they're far cheaper, but swords were the most common weapon on the battlefield during tons of conflicts. They were central to warfare from far antiquity (see Homer, the Iliad is filled with people using both together) through the early modern period.

>>56276179
I fenced for a bit, but it is so formalized that I don't think it really carries over much. Especially with foil. Saber is maybe more realistic, but there you can score with thrusts that wouldn't be effective in a real fight.

The bit of HEMA I've done with people who weren't afraid of slightly harder sparring I found spears to be far less useful if your opponent has a shield, but that might have been our adhoc scoring method. When you only score hits on thrusts with a spear, but count slashing with a sword, the sword has a distinct advantage, but in a real fight your armor would determine how effective either were.

The two handed sword seemed to have a distinct disadvantage against the spear, but if you think about the period that they were used, armor probably did a good deal to negate that. If armor is stopping the blade/point, the sword is able to generate blunt force injuries a lot better.

But for the most part, groups of men on the battlefield has a combination of weapons to make use of all the particular advantages and disadvantages.

threads.sub: Why is US ground force doctrine so asymmetrical?
threads.com:
I find it kinda interesting how asymmetrically US ground forces are doctrinally compared to US Naval and Air doctrine are. US Naval forces are all about being the pure dominator of the battle space. Nobody can challenge a US CSG in a fight other than another CSG. It’s about putting the most amount of force into the field and completely dominating the battle space.

On the other hand US ground doctrine is a lot more asymmetrical. Of course airland battle is the basis of modern US ground war fighting doctrine and was created when the US couldn’t have developed a force superiority on the ground against the USSR. So they focused on an asymmetrical way of fighting, which would aim to disrupt and destroy soviet command and control nodes as a way to cripple the soviet military in time for conventional defenses to be built up and the US’ industrial advantage to take effect.

Previous >>56179383
New cover when edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>56277310
Phosphates ability to hold lube only matters to phosphate because its roughness will also hold dirt and grime. Nitride, Nickel boron, and other surface treatments or coats dont hold dirt like phosphate does so they dont need to hold lube. The biggest issue with phosphate which is a small issue, is it is the least corrosion resistant finish to a BCG available. I have never had an issue with Nickel boron BCG, shitty manufacturers will always be shit. Hard chrome is along with Diamond like Carbon(DLC) the king of finishes, and NP3 is pretty great too, and improved nickel boron.
